title.value: Large-Scale Intrinsic Functional Brain Organization Emerges from Three Canonical Spatiotemporal Patterns
title.justification: The title accurately conveys the main focus of the study, which is the emergence of three canonical spatiotemporal patterns in the intrinsic functional brain organization.
title.quote: Large-Scale Intrinsic Functional Brain Organization Emerges from Three Canonical Spatiotemporal Patterns

extractions.description: The paper conducts a systematic survey of popular analytic techniques on resting-state fMRI data, finding that intrinsic functional brain organization can be reduced to three fundamental low-frequency spatiotemporal patterns.

type.justification: The study involves a systematic survey and analysis of resting-state fMRI data, which indicates an empirical approach.
type.quote: Our study conducted a systematic survey of popular analytic techniques and their output on a large sample of resting-state fMRI data.

name.justification: The paper discusses intrinsic functional brain organization, which is a central topic in neuroscience.
name.quote: The past decade of functional neuroimaging research has seen the application of increasingly sophisticated advanced methods to characterize intrinsic functional brain organization.

name.justification: The study applies functional neuroimaging techniques to investigate brain organization.
name.quote: The past decade of functional neuroimaging research has seen the application of increasingly sophisticated advanced methods to characterize intrinsic functional brain organization.

name.justification: The study specifically uses resting-state fMRI data to explore brain patterns.
name.quote: Our study conducted a systematic survey of a host of popular analytic techniques and their output on a large-sample of resting-state fMRI data.

name.justification: The dataset is explicitly mentioned as the source of the data used in the paper's analysis.
name.quote: Our study utilized resting-state fMRI scans from the Human Connectome Project (HCP) S1200 release.

referenced_paper_title.value: The WU-Minn Human Connectome Project: an overview
referenced_paper_title.justification: This referenced paper is the primary publication describing the Human Connectome Project dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The WU-Minn Human Connectome Project: an overview. Neuroimage 80, 62–79.

name.justification: This library is mentioned for data analysis and preprocessing in the study.
name.quote: Resting-state fMRI scans were spatially smoothed with a 5mm FWHM kernel using the surface-based smoothing algorithm in Connectome Workbench Version 1.4.2.

referenced_paper_title.value: Resting-state fMRI in the Human Connectome Project
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper is likely cited because it describes the preprocessing pipelines related to the Human Connectome Project.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Resting-state fMRI in the Human Connectome Project. Neuroimage 80, 144–168.

name.justification: The paper mentions the use of custom Python scripts for their analyses.
name.quote: All analyses were conducted using custom Python scripts, and are publicly-available at https://github.com/tsb46/BOLD_WAVES.

referenced_paper_title.value: Formal Models of the Network Co-occurrence Underlying Mental Operations
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper discusses various models and methods utilized in python, often involving machine learning and network analysis.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Formal Models of the Network Co-occurrence Underlying Mental Operations. PLOS Computational Biology 12, e1004994.
